title: Compiler part 1 - How to generate an exe?
description: So in this little series, I am going to be making a compiler and taking you along every step of the way!

children.value: Compiler part 1 - How to generate an exe?
So in this little series, I am going to be making a compiler and taking you along every step of the way!
To be clear, this won't be a tutorial per se, but I will show you every step along the way.
Also, I am not a professional compiler dev, this is a hobby and from my own experience.
And if you want a better resource for making languages, check out

, it is free online and goes over making an interpreter in huge detail. And yes I will make a compiler, but a lot of the concepts carry over, so if you ever get confused by this blog might try giving that a read;
Also having an understanding of Rust or C will help a lot in understanding some of the terms used (like pointer), I will try to explain stuff that isn't commonly known.

We are going to make a compiler in Rust, the lang will be simple with type inference!
Starting out with just numbers, then moving on to strings and even custom structs and classes.
Figure out how to make import systems, parse code into an AST (abstract syntax tree), how to resolve type information.
And most importantly how to generate LLVM IR and turn it into an exe that you can run independently.

We will also look a bit at how to create a good CLI interface for our compiler and how to handle errors.
Another issue that comes up is testing, if you aren't writing tests for your code you should! Although what is the best way to test a compiler? Well, what I will be doing is adding
statements to our language and running a bunch of smaller programs to see if they fail.

The lang itself is gonna be inspired by Python and Rust! Hence type inference, which means you won't have to declare the types of variables.
But arguments and return types you need to. an example of code in the lang might be:
is gonna be a statement as it makes debugging easier at the start before we have functions!
So how do we create an exe? Well, we could write all the bytes manually ourselves! But that is a lot of work and most importantly isn't cross-platform
Because each CPU is gonna have a separate set of assembly instructions, and even on the same CPU model different OSes are going to have different exe formats!
So what do we do? Well, we use LLVM IR.

So what is this magical LLVM IR I speak of? Well, it is a programming lang, well an IR (Intermediate Representation), basically, it is somewhere between assembly and a programming lang. Most langs are converted into some form of IR before then being compiled all the way down to an exe.
Many compilers also have a lang specific IR that they use before converting to the LLVM IR, and we are going to as well.
And we don't need to generate the LLVM IR text ourselves, there are tools to do it for us making it really convenient! We will be using
for this, it wraps the LLVM C library.
This is how we are going to structure our compiler, and over the following blog posts we will work on these parts!
let's just start very simple, we will hardcode some inkwell code to generate a simple "Hello World" script, in the next post we will start laying out the code structure of our compiler!
This step takes a while, the first few steps are slow but you can sit thru them fine.
The last build step on the other hand takes a VERY long time, so go watch a movie or something.
The LLVM install below is building from source, it is what I found worked for me, but you should try your package managers LLVM first and if it works then great! you saved yourself a lot of time
first, we need to add the inkwell library to our project.

props.code: cargo add inkwell --features llvm15-0

children.value:
now if you try to just run the code you get an error complaining that LLVM is not installed on your system (or maybe you don't in that case skip this step!)
You need to install LLVM, I am using Arch so will include instructions for that, but this should work on other Linux systems as well.
to build a local copy of the LLVM source code!

props.code:
cargo install llvmenv
llvmenv init

children.value: We will need to clone the LLVM project and switch to the version 15 branch (this is around a 2GB download)

props.code:
git clone https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project.git
cd llvm-project
git checkout release/15.x

children.value: then we will need to add this path to the list of LLVM versions

props.code:
[local-15]
path = "PATH_TO_YOUR_CLONED_REPO/llvm-project/llvm"
target = ["X86"]

children.value: Remember to specify where you cloned it, for example for me it is

(I just cloned it in my home folder).
also, you might need a different value for
, look at what it says for
on there, and now we can build it!
This is going to take a good while, for me it took an hour.

props.code: llvmenv build-entry local-15

children.value: Now we need to tell cargo where to find our new LLVM build, llvmenv would likely have installed it in

.
We can tell Rust how to find this using the
env var, you can either export it once:

props.code: export LLVM_SYS_150_PREFIX="/home/USERNAME/.local/share/llvmenv/local-15"

children.value: Alternatively you can save this in a file so cargo always uses it for this project (although that does make it hard to share the project with others, so be warned)
folder in the root of your project, then add a

props.code:
.cargo/
    config.toml
src/
    ...
Cargo.toml

children.value: in the file we can set build settings

props.code:
[env]
LLVM_SYS_150_PREFIX="/home/USERNAME/.local/share/llvmenv/local-15"

children.value: that way you don't have to export the path again each time you come back to the project!
Now that we got that installed, we can try to run our project again, (you might wanna do
first if you tried to build it earlier)
Okay, that was a lot of work (and time) for the first step
But now we can finally write some code!
So we are just gonna do this in

as a proof of concept, in the next post we will write a proper code structure with minimal implementations for each part of the compiler, and after that, we will have a technically fully working compiler, although it will be quite minimal. We will also tackle the CLI interface in the next post, so for now lets us just hardcode everything.

But first, we need to talk about lib-c, the standard library of C, we will be using it as well! You may ask, why are we using the stdlib from another lang, well simple, everybody is! The reason is that libc is implemented on basically any major platform you can imagine, and instead of dealing with OS specific terminal stuff, you can just use

props.code: use inkwell::{context::Context, AddressSpace};

children.value: now let's get started, we need to create some structs we will use to generate our code.
is basically a builder for generic stuff like types.
is what will contain our definitions and code, think of it as a file!
is what we use to generate code, we need to point it to the correct spot in the module, and we will get to that soon!
first let's declare some types we will be using later
We are going to use an
is basically just where in memory the pointer points to, we don't really have any specific requirements for this so the
So I mentioned we are going to use
, but we need to tell LLVM what the hell

is! When you are linking everything together there is no real concept of scope (except functions), all functions are in the same scope. so when we link with libc we get every function from libc in the global scope, but we need to declare what their types are as LLVM doesn't actually care about what libc is (with one exception, it does do optimizations around malloc/free).

props.code:
let printf_type = i32_type.fn_type(&[i8_ptr_type.into()], true);
let printf = module.add_function("printf", printf_type, None);

children.value: is basically the function signature, and what that line is saying is basically:
pointer, which is actually a string, a string is really just an array of characters, or
(but we don't have unsigned types in LLVM, so
It then takes a variable amount of arguments, that is what the
, which is rarely used, but represents how many chars were written, or a negative number for error.
then we add the function declaration to the module, under the name
, using the type we defined in the line above, the
is the linking option, for which we just leave it at default.
Have you ever wondered why basically every lang uses
? well, there is a reason! Did you know that the actual entry point to your program isn't
function for us, it does some setup like reading arguments, then it calls

with mains return code!
So if you wanted to create a lang without libc (like if you are targeting embedded systems) you need to define

instead!
But that is just some trivia for you, we are using libc, so we will define a

props.code:
let main_function_type = i8_type.fn_type(&[], false);
let main_function = module.add_function("main", main_function_type, None);

children.value:
, which will be the program's exit code, and we take no arguments.
now we can start generating our code!

props.code:
let main_block = context.append_basic_block(main_function, "entry");
builder.position_at_end(main_block);

children.value: So a block is basically a part of code, a jump target if you will, these blocks are what you can use

to jump to.
They are how we structure

, etc. basically any form of branching/repeating code. We only need one block, the name doesn't really matter, all it does is help with debugging and reading the produced IR. But I would still recommend giving stuff good names for your own sake.
to the end of the (empty) block, this means when we use the builder methods the code will be generated in this block!

props.code:
let string = builder.build_global_string_ptr("Hello World!", "output");
let string = string.as_pointer_value();

children.value: here we create a global string, basically a
and then convert it to a pointer (
call. And again, the name doesn't matter!

props.code: builder.build_call(printf, &[string.into()], "Print_Statement");

children.value:
This is very straightforward, we specify the function we wish to call, its arguments, and the name of the return value.
Now our code is basically done except, for one thing, our

props.code: builder.build_return(Some(&i8_type.const_int(0, false)));

children.value: int of value 0 (meaning no errors), don't worry about the
it is to enable a feature we don't need.
And now our code is finally done, we just need to save it!

props.code: module.print_to_file("output.ll").unwrap();

children.value: Our code should now look like this:
If we now run this code we should get a
file in our output directory,  it should look something like this:
if you are a VScode user you can use the following extension to get this syntax highligthed:

Now we can try to run this directly using LLVMs builtin interpreter, it is nice for quick testing!
You might need to add the LLVM bin directory to your path.

props.code:
export PATH=/home/USERNAME/.local/share/llvmenv/local-15/bin/:$PATH
lli output.ll

children.value:
You should see "Hello World" being printed on your terminal!
But this is a compiler, so let's make this into a binary, in the next post these steps will be added to your compiler itself!

props.code: llc output.ll -filetype=obj -o output.o

children.value: This will use the LLVM static compiler to compile your IR to an object file. An object file is basically almost a binary, it contains the assembly/machine code, but also symbol data, our code is converted into one object file, then a lot of object files are combined into one binary. This is how dependencies are added to your projects, it is also common to have each code file produce its own object file, it makes structuring the compiler easier. But ofc one issue we can run into is that we might have module scope with functions separated, but object files don't, so we need to handle that, but that is a future problem.
to compile the object file into a binary

props.code: clang output.o -no-pie -o output

children.value: ) to convert your object file to a final binary,
include libc by default so we don't have to worry about that. We also need to pass the
flag as the code we generate is not compatible with PIE binaries, because it uses absolute addresses.
We should now be able to run our binary!

props.code: ./output

children.value: and we should see the "Hello World" message!

If you followed along then congratulations! You now have a very hardcoded compiler, but you generated a binary from scratch!
In the next post we will start laying out the code components of the compiler and start generting binaries based on a input script file
If you have any questions feel free to leave them in the comments

Just a fair warning: This post is
long, Since it details the entire structure of the parser it takes a while.
So let's start by deleting the code we wrote last blog post! Yhe, Yhe I know, but it was just a proof of concept. now we are gonna write some real code!
Also forgot to mention this in the last post, the inkwell docs dont build correctly on docs.rs, use

I will also now be publishing the code on GitHub since we will be getting into a lot of files, should you ever be confused about where the code goes you can check there. I will use the same repo for each post, but I will link to specific commits in the posts (if you are unsure what version you are viewing the README should say).
The parts we will build today will work to support print statements of numbers, and that is all, in future posts, we will expand on this!
We will also have to decide, should we have multiple int types? I think we should have Both Float and Int, Float should be
, and we should have an implicit conversion from Int to Float (unlike
), but for now we shall only implement Int.
So to make this easier to change later we going to define some type aliases in
The type aliases are for use by our code in stuff like the IR and AST, while the
s are for the code generation!
For our command line interface we are going to use
, it is a fairly simple cli library, which is perfect for us. We are also going to

props.code:
carg add clap --features derive
cargo add anyhow
cargo add thiserror

children.value: We are going to put the CLI handling in
, and the rest of the code in
So for now we just gonna have the
command, in the future we will also have a
The interface will look like this:

props.code: our_compiler run input_file.viv

children.value: Well since we are running it via
to pass arguments to our code.

props.code: cargo run -- run input_file.viv

children.value: We will define an enum that will hold out different commands.
will be our sub-commands, for now just
will be the struct will all the CLI info, including future flags we will add.
We now need to actually parse the arguments, which is really simple.
, which is just a type alias for
, you might not know this but when you return an error from
rust will print it to stderr? Next, we call the
function from our Parser, this is provided by deriving
Now Clap gives us a lot of stuff for free! Like help messages:
And ofc we can run our command!
We also get good error messages!
We are also going to have some Debug flags, these are to help us when building the compiler!
/// Print the Internal ir to stdout
/// Print the produced LLVM ir to stdout
This will let us debug our compiler, and will be useful to make sure stuff is working as we progress thru the implementation of the compiler! The
means that these can be used anywhere on the command line, not just at the start, so
We will also need to set up some basic stuff in
Wait? Didn't we already define those compiler options? ...Well yes, but the reason we are doing this is that you cant import from

.
You might then be asking yourself, why not just move
? Well, we totally could! And you can do that if you want! Why aren't I? Well,
has CLI stuff in it, and personally, I want to keep that stuff in
We will then construct these Compiler options and pass them to
should be replaced with your project name, in the other files we will be using
Now that we got the CLI out of the way let's start doing some parsing!

Parsing is the work of taking text and turning it into a structure that makes sense and is easy to work with!
We are gonna do this in two steps, first, we tokenize the text, then we parse it.
Tokenizing basically takes the text and groups it into chunks that are easier to work with.

props.code:
src/
  parsing/
    mod.rs  <-- Create this file!
  lib.rs
  main.rs

children.value:
src/
  parsing/
    mod.rs  <-- Create this file!
  lib.rs
  main.rs
And ofc we need to add it to
(in the future I will just assume you do this when we create a new file)

props.code:
// lib.rs

mod parsing;

children.value: Now let's design our AST first, we will create an
module (in `parsing/), and we will also make the module public.

props.code:
// parsing/mod.rs

pub mod ast;

children.value: So for our AST, we could have a
struct, BUT we need to think about the future, so instead we will have
is a list of Statements, and here we use the type alias we set up at the start, so if you decide that you want bigger or smaller ints you can do that easily in

props.code:
print 1;
print 2;

Module(vec![
  Statement::Print(Expression::Literal(Literal::Integer(1))),
  Statement::Print(Expression::Literal(Literal::Integer(2)))
])

children.value:
Okay let's leave the Ast for and focus on tokens, these should be really small groups of meaningful data.
Consider the following code:

props.code: print 1 + 3;
PRINT, NUMBER(1), PLUS, NUMBER(3), SEMICOLON, EOF

children.value: the tokens are basically how you would read out the code if you were telling somebody how to write it!
file, (this one doesn't need to be public from

).
We will declare the tokens and tokenizer in the same file as they aren't that complex, while the Ast and Parser we split up because of their complexities (and also the parser doesn't need to be known outside
We will declare the tokens we need so far!
You may be asking, what is this
about? Well, we aren't going to use it (yet!), but it makes the tokenizing logic easier to have it now, in the future this will be used for variables!
We will also declare an error for the tokenizer so that we can get error messages for unknown chars!
Now we need to write the tokenizer, but first! I actually want to write a generic class in
as both the tokenizer and Parser are gonna use the same pattern!

So this class will be used by the tokenizer to consume chars, and by the parser to consume tokens. it lets us consume elements, look at what the next element is, and also ignore a value (useful after a peek). We also provide a general stream error!
Now that we got that implemented, let's create the tokenizer!
It is a good amount of code, and that isn't all of it, this is just the utility functions we will be using! They should all be pretty self-explanatory.
Also, you may ask, why are we using

We will call this when we hit a number, it will keep eating characters until it hits the end or a non-number char.
But wait, is that

I spot?! I thought you said we were gonna have good error handling!
But we are! In this case, since every char was checked with

This code is similar, we will call this on any alphabetic character, and identifiers can contain numbers in them.
After we read the identifier we check if it is a keyword (in this case we only got "print"), if not we create an Identifier.
This will let us remove whitespace easily, and this is why tokenizing is so useful, not only do we get identifiers and numbers grouped up when parsing, but we also don't have to deal with whitespace!
for comments, and ofc we just ignore it, another reason tokenizing is useful, the parser doesn't have to care about comments!
And here is our main function, it is rather straightforward when we got those other functions to do the hard work.
is it a digit? consume a number
is it a letter? consume an identifier
is it a semicolon? create a semicolon
is it whitespace? Consume and ignore
Also you might wonder, why are we taking ownership of
? simple, this struct wont be useful anymore once the stream is consumed, so to prevent errors we take ownership!
Now we can start writing the
, soon we will also add the parsing step to this
// we dont care about position info in this output
// This is inefficient! itertools has a more efficient join method, but I dont want to add a dependency just for that

Here we also use the compiler flags to maybe print out the tokens!
We also have a
at the end so Rust won't complain about our return type
And now we can actually test our code so far, let's write a test script
Now we can check what tokens we get!

props.code: cargo run -- run test.viv --output-tokens

children.value: You should get an output like

props.code: Print, Integer(1), SemiColon, Print, Integer(2), SemiColon, Eof

children.value: (You can ignore the panic, that is from the

We can also test some error handling now!
Try specifying a wrong file name, you should get a helpful error
Or add a symbol we haven't supported yet to the file!
Arent those errors just amazing? Always remember to test your error handling!

Now the more fun part starts! Writing a parser, we can do a very simple parsing because of how we will design the language, basically, we can always know what we are about to parse by looking at the current token.
, great we are about to parse a print statement, is it a

... well you get the point!
And no not all langs are like this,  consider Pythons list comps!
token you dont know if it is a list comp or a normal list you are parsing, you don't know that until you hit the
token. but we will be careful and avoid issues like this.
"Parser error on line {line}, char {char}: expected one of {expected}, got {got:?}"

Our parsing errors are generally just going to be along the lines of "expected RIGHT_PAREN got PLUS" and stuff like that.
Or like "expected one of
Here we generate the error from the got token and the expected ones.
This is the general structure of the parser, we are mainly going to be using
to parse the different things that could show up!
let's start from the bottom and work up:

It is really straightforward really, we check what we are currently at then call the needed function.
Let's add this to our
We can now run our code on the same file

props.code: cargo run -- run test.viv --output-ast

children.value: And you should get something like:

Oh boy this got long, but now we should have a fully working parser generating our ast, In the next blog we will create the internal IR and type analyzer, they should be much simpler than this, so we might fit in the code generation as well! So stay tuned

title: Compiler part 2.2 - Type analysis and Code geneation!
description: So in the last blog post, we created the parsing module that generated our AST! Today we will be generating the internal IR, code generation (what we did in part 1, but now based on our IR!), and then also adding those shell commands we used afterward to the compiler itself.

children.value: Compiler part 2.2 - Type analysis and Code geneation!
So in the last blog post, we created the

module that generated our AST! Today we will be generating the internal IR, code generation (what we did in part 1, but now based on our IR!), and then also adding those shell commands we used afterward to the compiler itself.
The full code for this post can be found at
This step is basically "figure out what everything is!", we basically apply a bunch of rules to give every part of our compiler a type
This might sound hard, but it is rather simple, code might be something along the lines of

props.code:
if plus.left == int a&& plus.right == int {plus.result = int}
else {error(...)}

children.value: Our IR will contain type information in contrast to the AST, we could encode this using fields (and we will for dynamic types like structs.). While the AST represents what the code looks like, the IR should represent what the code
This also gives us a benefit from the rust compiler, We can't for example construct an

type print and give it a String by accident!
This ensures we do the type analysis correctly.
Now we can do some type analyzing, with so few instructions it is rather simple:
So why this enum? Well consider
, we don't know what the type should be when we walk an expression, so what is the return type? This is one of those times you would want a union, but in Rust, we shall use more enums!
Again here we use the power of abstraction! Very simple so far, but even with more complex rules this will stay simple

This should also be really clear, and a bit similar to the parsing. And in a way, we are just "parsing" the AST into an IR.
Now that we have this let's try to print it out!
you should get something like the following:
Now we are gonna turn this IR into some actual code! Using
the same way we did in Part 1.

You will see a lot of the same structs here, with the addition of the fpm, it is the optimizer!
We don't have to write it ourselves! So instead of worrying about if we should optimize stuff, just don't first and see if LLVM does it for you, if it does, then great less work for us! So always try the simple stuff first, like we will output every variable on the heap, but LLVM will promote them to registers where it works.
We also have this so the Int width in

is easier to work (this means we are restricted to these options.)
Now we can actually do some code gen:
// In the future we will have functions, for now put everything in main()
We need to add the libc functions definitions we will be using, we will be using more in the future so stay tuned

The most complex part here is the print statement, but it should look very similar to what we did in part 1! We just do some conditional selecting of the formatting string, so the constructed call might look like

We can now save this, and here is a small optimization I will do! In the last post we used the text version of LLVM IR, but there is a bytecode version that will take up less space and be more efficient!

And yes we do generate the output twice if we have the debug flag set, but it is a debug flag, it doesn't really matter.
We also run optimization in this part because we already have the compiler options!
Now we just have to call this from our
function, but one question, in what file should we save the result? well, here the
crate will help us! it will allow us to create temporary files for use during compiling!

props.code: cargo add temp-file

children.value: then we can generate and use our temporary file
Now we need to compile this LLVM IR down to a binary, to do this we will spawn subprocesses of
To do this we will create some helper functions!
These two functions will let us search the
env variable for the command line tools we need to invoke!
We then use these to do our 2 steps in compiling from an LLVM ir to a binary
"Clang or gcc not found on path"
Then we can use these in the
let's update our Run code to generate an output file and run it
if we now just run our script,
being printed on the terminal! Congratulations! We now have a fully working compiler
Just one last thing I want to add before we wrap up, add a
command, what use is a compiler if we can't save our binary?
we can now test our new command.

props.code:
cargo run -- build test.viv test 
./test

children.value: So today we made a complete compiler, fair enough it does only support printing numbers, but my god wasn't it fun! So much learning, if you want you can go ahead and play with this, try changing the syntax, and maybe even add more features yourself?

In the next post we will create the next obvious feature booleans!
... wait really? booleans? we don't even have operators!
And yhe you are right, it is a bit unusual, our first operator will be
, but there is a good reason. I want to start writing integration tests, and for that, we need
But we will do that next! If you have any questions feel free to leave them in the comments below.

title: Compiler Part 3 - Integration testing
description: In todays blog post we are going to implement assert so we can start writing tests.

children.value: In todays blog post we are going to implement
so we can start writing tests.
And as always you can find the code

Simple, testing, we could test using stdout, but that gets annoying as we need to keep track of expected output somewhere, and an assert statement is just way more convenient. Our assert statement is gonna take the format of
(message will be optional). That means we will add string to our tokenizer today! but we wont implement full on strings until later posts.
We are going to start with just
at the end. This will also give us a look at how
s are structured, as that is really all asserts are!

props.code: assert x == 2, "stuff broke";

children.value: So now that we are writing tests breaking changes are gonna become annoying as we have to update tests. So we are going to avoid them as best we can!
Put that posses a question, we dont have a
function yet, we dont have functions at all. Should we add the very minimal to support
, or just have stuff at the top level? But then in the future should we ever add
and what does that mean? If we dont we have to somehow separate the stuff that should go in
and what is actually top level, and that would only work in the
file! In other words it is a bit of a pain :/
So we need a way to specify a
, but also do we want to have
be some special name like every other lang out there, or should we be a snowflake? Since doing half the work of adding functions is kinda annoying, we could have special syntax for main!
It is a bit unusual to be sure, but I think this might work for us!
So we are gonna now introduce two type of statement, TopLevel and Normal statements, TopLevel is stuff like imports, functions, main, struct. While normal is stuff like assignment, print, if, etc...
We are going to need some new tokens, for

props.code:

pub enum TokenType {
    Integer(IntType),
    Identifier(String),
    Print,
    SemiColon,
    Dollar,
    CurlyOpen,
    CurlyClose,
    Eof,
}

Then we can add it to the parser, it is fairly simple change,
The IR has a similar modification:
Then we can modify the code gen to create the main part using this IR.
Now you should be able to run
Now we will add booleans, finally another type!
In the future I will likely not show all these parts, just saying something like "we add a token
Then we will add a new
And then we modify the literal parsing
Now lets add boolean expression to our IR!
Then we modify the type analyzer!
// This isnt the best way to do this
Yes we just represent a bool as
Now we are gonna add our
statement, it will basically be compiled to:
Then afterwards we will add a test runner, so we can start writing tests! And then we will add
so the assert can actually do something.
We are going to need a
. But you should understand how to add those now!
And then we add a new
And then we do the parsing while handling the optional message.
Lets add our Assert statement to the IR
Then we add it to the type resolver!
method which will produce an error if the user dares give us an int!
And now for the fun part, code gen! I mentioned that we could use blocks when doing
s, well asserts are just implicit
s, so we will create 2 blocks for the assert, "Continue" and "Failure". We are also going to need
to make our job easier, then we create a branch. So
If you run this you should see
printed, and if you run with
you might have expected to see the assert code in there... but we dont? why?
Optimizations! if you also run with

you now see the assert logic, but LLVM figured out that it is always True so just removed it! great for speed, but there is one downside, LLVM might remove code that weren't being used by accident. Say we had a bug that somehow caused our
to give out the wrong result, llvm would just optimize away the comparison itself and just leave us with the code that would get run. oh no! that is why the
flag is so important for debugging, if the llvm ir doesn't match what you would expect always try running with that first to see what we actually generated.
Well we got asserts, now lets write some tests! This is gonna be pretty simple, we will loop over all files in
Lets add some tests right now!
Surely this should not fail! But you never known
/// Compile and run all files in integration_tests/
and it should run the test.
so we can actually test stuff! We will implement this for numbers, then in the next blog post we will add other comparisons, logic operators and binary ops.
Now we are going to start doing some TTD, so lets write some tests first!
Now we are getting into double symbols, we could have just a
symbol, but, we will have a
at this time even though we wont use it yet.
We will add a function to help us eat these double symbols
Then we will add comparisons to our AST!
because we cant have recursive types, because it would be infinitely large, but
puts the object on the heap, meaning we it isnt a problem!
Now parsing binary ops is actually a good amount of work, at least when we have multiple. Why you ask? Order of operations! We might parse
if we just go right to left, which is fine, but
, which is not good. So we need to parse them in the correct order, and we need to do it in a way that is easy to add more operators later.

So how are we gonna do that? We aren't! ... what? Well it is a bit of work, and not the focus of this blog post. And we only have one operator so far so it wont be an issue, but we will get back to this in the next post!
Now we add the IR for the binary op
This is a bit more complex than the AST, but again type info! So all these types are needed to make code gen easy
In the next post we will make this proper, but for now it is pretty hardcoded.
And now the fun part begins, code gen!
And now running our test should work!
And congratulations! We now have a working testing framework, this is gonna make our future development much more convenient. in the next post we will add more fun tests like
! But we will go into that in detail in the next post.

title: "Compiler Part 4 - Operators"
description: In the last post we implemented the == operator, and we just did a very simple implementation, but today we will start adding more fun operators.

children.value: In the last post we implemented the
operator, and we just did a very simple implementation, but today we will start adding more fun operators.
And as always you can find the code
We will add the classic math operators for ints,
, and we will also add the
operator for bools, in addition to
. We will also add the comparison operators,
Now a little note on prefix operators, it might be clear that
is a operator. but what about stuff like
? well it is a prefix and infix operator, so we are going to parse
? To make it easy ofc! We will use the same parsing logic for
etc. (and yes we will be adding parentheses as well!)
This is basically order of operations, so
. First lets define some terms, "lower" precedence means that the operator is evaluated first, so
, and "higher" precedence means that the operator is evaluated last, so
A nice way of thinking about this in terms of parsing is glue,
. But this isnt just for operators, but expressions as a whole.

so in the big picture it goes: Operator > Function call > Parentheses > Literals.
You might assume that prefix operators have a lower precedence than binary operators, but that is not the case. for example
Also multiple operators can have the same precedence, like
, but in that case we just read right to left!
This is gonna be a bit of a challenge, but we will get through it! Parsing prefix is pretty easy, but binary is where it gets annoying.
So you might assume we will do something like:
, all fine right? but what about
, but that isnt right, it should got right to left! This is a bit annoying to parse, you might be trying to think of how to do this, and the trick is
use recursion! We will use a loop instead, it will look something like:
Note: this is just pseudo code, it wont look like this exactly, but it is just to show the idea.
This will parse it and build up the
Another thing we should consider is comparison chaining like
, we could just convert this to the same IR as
, but that does run into an issue of calculating one side twice. imagine
(this code doesn't really make sense), but we dont want it to print twice! So we will add comparison chaining to the ir as well!
So we are going to have a list of levels, with enums for the different types. but we will also hardcode some parts, like once we hit the end of the list we will call
for example, because that is easiest!
We are gonna start with the simple prefix operators, so

.
and as always we add a test:
)! Then we will modify the ast!
Then comes the job of parsing this stuff! So remember how we made that
function in the last post that did nothing? well now we will make it do something!

We will use this enum to handle precedence. So we will make a list of operators, and then we will loop through them and parse them. This list feels like it should be a const, or maybe static? But one issue... we cant use
in a static, we could just create a new instance on each call, but that is stupid. We could store the list on the Parser struct, which is not a bad idea, and you can totally go for that if you want.

, which is a macro that lets us create a static that is lazily evaluated, so it is only evaluated once, and then it is stored. So we will create a static list of operators, and then we will loop through them and parse them.
Wether this is good code is up to you, personally this is a thing I like to have as a const/static, and

is a nice way to do it.
And yes we do remove
for now, we will add it back later. This does mean that test we just added wont work, but by the end of the post the tests should be working again!
method I added last post? yhe delete it!
The first part we get the operator level, and if we hit the end of the list we parse a literal (we will change this to
later). The prefix code is simple enough, we check if the operator is present, if it is we parse an expression with the same precedence (we allow chaining the same operator, so
Now in the IR we will add a variant for the prefix actions directly, why? simple, there is only one for each type
The type resolving code is fairly simple for this:
This function is starting to get a bit crowded, so lets do some refactoring shall we?
Now code gen is pretty simple because of inkwell:
Now running the tests wont work because of the missing
operator, but we will add that now!

Now we have to deal with chaining!
But first tests!
so you should add tokens for
Then we can modify the ast
// Also remove `Equals` from the binary operators
Here we use a Vector to store the comparisons, so we can chain them. And you can chain multiple different ones if you want, like
. We will also need to add comparisons to our
would be more efficient, but this is fine for now. If you have a performance issue you can change it later.
This code basically loops while there is still a comparison token, and then it creates the chain!
We modify the IR in a similar way to the AST:
is similar to the AST version.
And then we solve the types, for now you can delete the code in
in there!), then we will add an resolve comparison, for now we only got int comparisons, so that should be easy.
Code gen is also pretty simple, we just need to add a new function for the comparison:
and ofc then use this in
So we basically loop over each pair of expressions, and then we compare them, and then we
Running our tests we see them all work! But we still have to add the binary operators!

So now integers, time to do some MATH! YAY!
And as always, tests!
Okay so you need to add the
tokens to the tokenizer, and then the
, etc, to the AST. And then we need to add them to the
Then we do our parsing logic!
Here we build up the left side one operator at a time!
The IR is simple to modify:
The type resolution is gonna be very similar to the comparison!
This is going to be very similar, in fact I trust you can do it yourself! But I will give you the tests:
Then you will add tokens for
, but we wont use those yet!)
tokens to the AST, and then we add them to the
The ir modification is the same as with the int, and same for the type resolution! You should be able to figure those out yourself!
Now, we need to decide wether we want short-circuit or not, what do I mean with this? If say we had
the right hand side wont get executed if we short-circuit, because we already know the result will be true! But if we dont short-circuit it will get executed, and then we will check the result.
Short-circuits require more work because we need to check the result of the left side and then decide wether to execute the right side or not. And this gets tricky, because you might model this as:
But there is an issue, we cant just create code like this in LLVM! Why? well in LLVM every var is immutable, so we cant just assign to the same value in multiple locations
What will we do? We will allocate the value on the stack and store a reference to it, this isnt like a normal pointer, it is a abstract idea in LLVM land. So it might actually look like:

This is a bit annoying, but it is the only way to do it. We will do that same thing when we add variables later. And ofc LLVM will optimize away this check if the result is clear and so on, like if you did
it will be optimized to just
Okay lets describe the short-circuits in detail, we will use truth tables to see this clearly.
then the result is the right side, and for
then the result is the right side.
We also have to consider what the result is when we do short circuit, for
First we compile the left side, then we create our blocks, we need one for the right hand case, one for the short-circuit case, and ofc one for the continue after the check.
We then create the allocated "pointer", and then we create the branch based on the operator type, you might have expected to see a
in there, but we can just swap the branches and we get the same effect.
Then in the right hand side block we compile the right hand side, and then we store it in the pointer, and then we jump to the continue block.
Similar in the short block we decide what the result should be and then we store that in the pointer, and then we jump to the continue block.
In the continue block we load our value!
Now lets add groups, i.e parenthesis, this lets us "break" precedence,
, The code thing is that this is totally in the parsing stage, we dont even have to touch the AST! Because the ast already encodes the precedence, so we just need to change the parsing logic!
But we do have to add new tokens,
We now have operators, so basically we got a very overgrown calculator! Yay! Now we can start adding more fun stuff, like variables, control flow, functions, etc.

title: Compiler part 5 - Variables
description: So in todays blog post we will be implementing variables. This is what will make this more than a overgrown calculator and start looking more like a real programming lang.

children.value: So in todays blog post we will be implementing variables. This is what will make this more than a overgrown calculator and start looking more like a real programming lang.
And as always here is the repo:
How shall we keep track of scope
So the question of scope, how big should scopes be? We can do what python does and have function scope, or like rust with blog scope. what do I mean with this?
How rust and python do it.
# x and y go out of scope
in python this works, while in rust this wont:
// Error, x is not in scope
In rust this wont work because

goes out of scope at the end of the if block.
How does rust deal with something like this then? Well for one we need a else case, because if the condition doesn't run then x might be undefined!
And we can then make a mutable
// x and y goes out of scope
Although in rust this is better written using a if-expression, because it avoids the mut.

The benefit of rusts smaller scopes is that you can never have a undefined var, like we saw in the first rust snippet. We could do similar to python, and check that every branch declares a variable, some python linters actually do this.

But that is a lot of work, and it is easier to have smaller scope. But then we run into the issue of what if we do want to affect vars in the outer scope.
One easy option is having separate syntax for declaring and modifying variables.
And that is what we will do. And we will make it simple and have all vars be mutable.
We already know the type of the expression so we can use that to determine the type. And then on writes check that the type matches.
How should we store vars in the LLVM
We are going to be storing them on the stack, same way we did during the short circuiting logic. where we used
value on the stack so we could modify it in the different branches, like we did in rust above.
Another important thing is that you likely noticed during out short-cutting logic that we never free the
, because it does it for us,
at the end of the function
, and that means that we should

to mean "free everything"
The naive way would be.

And you can see that this will leak a LOT of memory.
meanwhile what we should do is collect all vars that will be created in a function beforehand and then allocate them at the start of the function:
Since all this logic needs to be applied to all functions, including main, we are going to make main just a normal function on the
And then in our type analyzer we will include "main" as the function name:
And then we use this name in the code gen:
Yes we are still hardcoding the return type and statement, when we add proper function support we will rework that.

We are going to have a two scope structs. Function scope and block scope. As mentioned we need to allocate the vars at the start of the function, so the function scope will store a reference to all the vars.
Meanwhile the block scope will be used during type resolution. We are going be to be generating unique ids for the vars, because for example here we are referring to different xs.
And ofc here are the tests:
We need add a token for
, and then lets modify the ast:
We also add a variable expression in the
And we can use the same parsing for
And we will parse that literal as well:
First lets add the assignment to the IR!
So now we need some global state in the type analyzer, which means we need to make it into a struct, something I
should have done from the start... So just wrap it in a struct and add
to all the functions and also
in front of the method calls. (if you want a shortcut just copy from the github repo).
These will help us keep track of the state as we resolve the types.
Then we will store the metadata, in our analyzer:
Because of this chang we now need to change how we are calling the type analyzer.
Then when we analyze a function (in this case just main) we setup the metadata:
When we analyze a declaration we add the variable to the current scope and the list of the functions locals vars.
And for assignment we read the metadata and check that the type matches:
"expression is of type {var_type:?}, but variable {name} is not."
And then analyzing the variable expression is similar:
We also need to add some metadata to our code generator, as we need to store references to the pointer values:
One error I noticed because of the changes we are about to make is that every return value we have (at least those returning inkwell structs) should have
s at the start of the function, and store a reference to the pointers in the

hash map.
Then in the assignment we can lookup the pointer in the hashmap and use it:
And when we have a var expression we just load the type (and convert it to the expected one):
It is the same for integers
And now we should have variables, yay!
Fixing a pretty big flaw in our boolean logic
When we did the boolean short circuiting logic in the last blog post we just used
at the operator location, but as we discussed above this might put the
in a loop, which would be really bad. to solve this we will also add vars when we analyze a boolean operation and use that var when doing short circuiting.
We will add a variable reference to the boolean operator ir:
We will add a variable reference when we resolve a bool:

props.code:
let result_identifier = self.get_free_identifier();
self.function_metadata
    .as_mut()
    .unwrap()
    .locals
    .push((result_identifier, ir::VarType::Boolean));

Ok(TypedExpression::Boolean(ir::BooleanExpression::Operator(
    result_identifier,
    Box::new(left),
    op,
    Box::new(right),
)))

children.value: Now in the code gen instead of using a new pointer we will load one from the local vars:
And now we should be avoiding memory leaks in out boolean operators.
Now that we have variables this is looking more like a proper language, in the next post we will be adding control flow, like
, etc. So look forward to that!

How should we store vars in the LLVM
Fixing a pretty big flaw in our boolean logic
